sections.title: Torque and Angular Momentum
sections.description: Introduction of torque as the rotational equivalent of force and angular momentum as the rotational equivalent of linear momentum.

content.introduction: Force causes acceleration; Torque causes angular acceleration. Momentum describes translational 'quantity of motion'; Angular Momentum describes rotational 'quantity of motion'.

coreConcepts.explanation: Torque \(\vec{\tau}\) is defined as the cross product of the position vector \(\vec{r}\) (from origin to point of force application) and the force \(\vec{F}\): \( \vec{\tau} = \vec{r} \times \vec{F} \). It represents the turning effect of a force.
coreConcepts.example: Pushing a door handle (large r) creates more torque than pushing near the hinges (small r).
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Diagram of a wrench turning a nut. Force applied perpendicular to the handle maximizes torque.

coreConcepts.explanation: Angular momentum \(\vec{l}\) of a particle is defined as \( \vec{l} = \vec{r} \times \vec{p} \). For a system, \(\vec{L} = \sum \vec{l}_i\). The rate of change of angular momentum equals the net external torque: \( \frac{d\vec{L}}{dt} = \vec{\tau}_{ext} \).

microsections.title: Historical Models and the Concept of Gravity

content.introduction: Since ancient times, humanity has observed the sky, noting the regular motion of stars and the wandering paths of planets. Early attempts to explain these motions led to various models, evolving from Earth-centered views to the modern understanding of universal gravitation.

coreConcepts.explanation: The Geocentric model, championed by Ptolemy, placed the Earth at the center of the universe with celestial bodies revolving around it. This model held sway for nearly 2000 years. In the 16th century, Nicholas Copernicus proposed the Heliocentric model, placing the Sun at the center with planets, including Earth, orbiting it in circles. Galileo's telescopic observations later provided crucial evidence supporting the heliocentric view.
coreConcepts.example: Galileo observed the phases of Venus and the moons of Jupiter, which contradicted the geocentric model's predictions.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: A diagram contrasting the Ptolemaic system (Earth-center) with the Copernican system (Sun-center).

coreConcepts.explanation: While Kepler defined *how* planets move, he did not explain *why*. Isaac Newton realized that the force causing an apple to fall to the ground is the same force keeping the Moon in orbit around the Earth. This unification of terrestrial and celestial mechanics is the foundation of the concept of gravitation.
coreConcepts.example: Newton compared the acceleration of the Moon towards Earth with the acceleration of a falling object on Earth.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Illustration of Newton's thought experiment: a cannonball fired from a mountain top with increasing speed until it orbits the Earth.

summary: The shift from geocentric to heliocentric models marked a revolution in astronomy.
Gravitation is a universal force acting between all matter.
Newton unified terrestrial gravity and planetary motion under one theory.

content.introduction: Johannes Kepler, using the precise data of Tycho Brahe, derived three fundamental laws that describe how planets orbit the Sun.

coreConcepts.explanation: All planets move in elliptical orbits with the Sun situated at one of the foci of the ellipse. This deviated from the previous belief in perfect circular orbits.
coreConcepts.example: The distance between the Earth and the Sun changes throughout the year because the orbit is an ellipse, not a circle.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: An ellipse with the Sun at one focus and a planet orbiting it, showing perihelion and aphelion.

coreConcepts.explanation: The line that joins any planet to the Sun sweeps out equal areas in equal intervals of time. This implies that the areal velocity $\frac{dA}{dt}$ is constant. Consequently, planets move faster when they are closer to the Sun (perihelion) and slower when they are farther away (aphelion).
coreConcepts.example: Earth moves fastest in early January when it is closest to the Sun.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: A diagram showing a planet at two different positions in its orbit, shading equal areas swept in equal time.

coreConcepts.explanation: The square of the time period of revolution of a planet is proportional to the cube of the semi-major axis of the ellipse traced out by the planet. Mathematically, $T^2 \propto a^3$ or $\frac{T^2}{a^3} = \text{constant}$.
coreConcepts.example: Jupiter takes nearly 12 Earth years to orbit the Sun because its semi-major axis is much larger than Earth's.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Graph of $T^2$ vs $a^3$ showing a straight line.

content.introduction: Newton proposed that the force of attraction between any two particles of matter in the universe is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them.

coreConcepts.explanation: The magnitude of the gravitational force $F$ between two masses $m_1$ and $m_2$ separated by a distance $r$ is given by: $$F = G \frac{m_1 m_2}{r^2}$$ where $G$ is the universal gravitational constant. The force is attractive and acts along the line joining the two particles.
coreConcepts.example: If you double the mass of one object, the force doubles. If you double the distance, the force reduces to one-fourth.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Two spheres of mass m1 and m2 separated by distance r, showing force vectors pointing towards each other.

coreConcepts.explanation: Gravitation is a vector quantity. In vector notation: $$\vec{F}_{12} = -G \frac{m_1 m_2}{r^2} \hat{r}_{21}$$ Here, $\vec{F}_{12}$ is the force on body 1 due to body 2, and $\hat{r}_{21}$ is the unit vector pointing from 2 to 1. The negative sign indicates the force is attractive (opposite to the radial vector).
coreConcepts.example: The force exerted by Earth on the Moon is equal and opposite to the force exerted by the Moon on Earth (Newton's 3rd Law).
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Vector diagram showing F12 and F21 acting in opposite directions.

Force is inversely proportional to square of distance.

content.introduction: The universal gravitational constant, $G$, is a fundamental physical constant appearing in Newton's law of gravitation. It represents the strength of the gravitational interaction.

coreConcepts.explanation: The accepted value of $G$ is approximately $6.67 \times 10^{-11} \text{ N m}^2/\text{kg}^2$. It is a scalar quantity. Note that $G$ is very small, which explains why gravity is a weak force on the scale of everyday objects.

sections.title: Acceleration due to gravity of the earth
sections.description: Analysis of the acceleration experienced by objects near the Earth's surface.

content.introduction: When an object falls near the Earth's surface, it accelerates. This acceleration is denoted by 'g'. We can derive its value using the Universal Law of Gravitation.

coreConcepts.explanation: Consider a body of mass $m$ on the surface of Earth (mass $M$, radius $R$). The gravitational force is $F = \frac{GMm}{R^2}$. By Newton's 2nd law, $F = mg$. Equating these: $$mg = \frac{GMm}{R^2} \implies g = \frac{GM}{R^2}$$
coreConcepts.example: Plugging in Earth's mass ($6 \times 10^{24}$ kg) and radius ($6.4 \times 10^6$ m) gives $g \approx 9.8 \text{ m/s}^2$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Diagram showing Earth with radius R and a small mass m on the surface.

coreConcepts.explanation: The formula $g = \frac{GM}{R^2}$ does not contain the term $m$ (mass of the object). This explains Galileo's observation that all objects fall with the same acceleration, regardless of their mass (ignoring air resistance).
coreConcepts.example: A feather and a hammer fall at the same rate on the Moon (where there is no air).
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Image of the Apollo 15 experiment dropping a hammer and feather.

content.introduction: The value of $g$ is maximum at the Earth's surface. It decreases as we go up into space or down into a mine.

coreConcepts.explanation: At a height $h$ above the surface, the distance from the center is $R+h$. The value of gravity is $g_h = \frac{GM}{(R+h)^2}$. For small heights ($h \ll R$), we can use the binomial approximation: $$g_h \approx g \left(1 - \frac{2h}{R}\right)$$
coreConcepts.example: At the top of Mount Everest (h=8.8km), g is slightly less than 9.8 m/s^2.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Graph showing g decreasing as 1/r^2 as distance increases from surface.

coreConcepts.explanation: At a depth $d$ below the surface, only the inner sphere of radius $(R-d)$ contributes to gravity (Shell Theorem). The formula is: $$g_d = g \left(1 - \frac{d}{R}\right)$$ At the center of the Earth ($d=R$), $g$ becomes zero.
coreConcepts.example: At a depth of R/2, gravity is half the surface value.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Graph showing linear decrease of g inside the Earth and curve decay outside.

sections.title: Gravitational potential energy

content.introduction: Gravitational potential energy is the energy possessed by a body due to its position in a gravitational field. It is defined as the work done in bringing a body from infinity to a given point.

coreConcepts.explanation: The gravitational potential energy $U$ of a system of two masses $M$ and $m$ separated by distance $r$ is: $$U = -\frac{GMm}{r}$$ The reference point is usually taken at infinity, where $U = 0$.
coreConcepts.example: As a rock falls towards Earth, r decreases, so U becomes more negative (decreases), and kinetic energy increases.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Graph of Potential Energy vs distance r, showing a curve in the negative quadrant approaching zero as r approaches infinity.

coreConcepts.explanation: The negative sign indicates that the force is attractive. Energy must be supplied (positive work) to move the mass away from the gravitational field (to infinity). The system is in a bound state.
coreConcepts.example: To separate the Earth and Moon completely, we would need to add energy to the system.

content.introduction: Escape speed is the minimum initial velocity a body must have to escape the gravitational pull of a planet and never return.

coreConcepts.explanation: By conservation of energy, the total energy at the surface (Kinetic + Potential) must equal the total energy at infinity (which is 0). $$\frac{1}{2}mv_e^2 - \frac{GMm}{R} = 0 \implies v_e = \sqrt{ rac{2GM}{R}}$$ Or in terms of g: $v_e = \sqrt{2gR}$.
coreConcepts.example: For Earth, $v_e \approx 11.2$ km/s.

content.introduction: Satellites are objects that revolve around a planet. They are held in orbit by the gravitational pull, which provides the necessary centripetal force.

coreConcepts.explanation: For a satellite of mass $m$ orbiting at distance $r$ from the center of Earth (mass $M$), the gravitational force provides centripetal acceleration: $\frac{GMm}{r^2} = \frac{mv_o^2}{r}$. coreConcepts.explanation: The time taken for one complete revolution is $T = \frac{2\pi r}{v_o}$. Substituting $v_o$: $$T = 2\pi \sqrt{ rac{r^3}{GM}}$$ This confirms Kepler's third law ($T^2 \propto r^3$).
coreConcepts.example: Low Earth orbit satellites take about 90 minutes to circle Earth.

content.introduction: An orbiting satellite possesses both kinetic energy (due to motion) and potential energy (due to position).

coreConcepts.explanation: Potential Energy: $U = -\frac{GMm}{r}$. Kinetic Energy: $K = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = \frac{1}{2}m(\frac{GM}{r}) = \frac{GMm}{2r}$. Note that $|U| = 2K$.
coreConcepts.example: The potential energy is twice the magnitude of the kinetic energy.

sections.description: Comparison of different types of satellite orbits and their applications.

content.introduction: Satellites are classified based on their orbits. Two major types are Geostationary and Polar satellites, each serving different purposes.

coreConcepts.explanation: These satellites orbit the Earth in the equatorial plane with a time period of 24 hours, matching Earth's rotation. As a result, they appear stationary relative to a point on Earth. They orbit at a height of approx 35,800 km.
coreConcepts.example: Used for telecommunications and weather forecasting (fixed view).

coreConcepts.explanation: These satellites orbit in a north-south direction, passing over the poles. They usually orbit at lower altitudes (500-800 km). Since Earth rotates beneath them, they can scan the entire surface of the Earth over time.
coreConcepts.example: Used for remote sensing, spy photography, and environmental monitoring.

sections.title: Weightlessness
sections.description: Understanding the phenomenon of weightlessness in orbit and free fall.

content.introduction: Astronauts in the International Space Station float freely. This state is called weightlessness, but it doesn't mean gravity is absent.

coreConcepts.explanation: Our sensation of weight comes from the reaction force (Normal force) exerted by the ground on our feet. If this reaction force is zero, we feel weightless. In an elevator falling with acceleration $g$, the normal force $N = m(g-a) = m(g-g) = 0$.
coreConcepts.example: The feeling in your stomach when a roller coaster drops suddenly.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Free body diagram of person in a falling elevator showing N=0.

coreConcepts.explanation: A satellite is essentially in a state of perpetual free fall towards Earth. The astronaut and the satellite fall at the same rate. Therefore, the satellite exerts no normal force on the astronaut, resulting in weightlessness.
coreConcepts.example: Water forms floating spheres in the ISS.
